## 

```{r}
train <- read.csv("../../../data/train.csv", stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
```

## Histogram of scores

```{r}
hist(train$score, breaks=40)
hist(scale(train$score), breaks=40)
```
## Table of reference aa frequencies

```{r, fig.width=10}
table(train$ref_short)
barplot(table(train$ref_short), main = "Frequency of Ref", ylab="Frequency", xlab="AA")
```
## Table of alternate aas

```{r, fig.width=10}
table(train$alt_short)
barplot(table(train$alt_short))
```

## Table of ref_alt

```{r, fig.width=8, fig.height=60}
table(paste0(train$ref_short, "_", train$alt_short))
barplot(table(paste0(train$ref_short, "_", train$alt_short)), xlab="REF-ALT Pair", ylab="Frequency", horiz = TRUE, las=2, cex.names=0.5)

```

Are all pairs represented in dataset?  ~ 400 states...
There are some ref aa == alt aa's different nt codon producing same aa?

```{r, fig.width=10}
boxplot(score~ref_short, data = train, cex=0.5, pch=19)
```

```{r, fig.width=10}
boxplot(score~alt_short, data = train, pch=19, cex=0.5)
```

```{r, fig.height=40, fig.width=5}
boxplot(score~ref_short+alt_short, data = train, pch=19, cex=0.5, horizontal = TRUE, las=2, cex.axis=0.5)
```

## Quarto

Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see <https://quarto.org>.

## Running Code

When you click the **Render** button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

```{r}
1 + 1
```

You can add options to executable code like this

```{r}
#| echo: false
2 * 2
```

The `echo: false` option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).
